title: Effects of Poverty and Education level on CA County AQI
description:
Final project for EDS 222: Statistics for Data Science.
Fall 2021

title: summarize() Function
description: Description and example of the summarize() function
contents:
summarize() function:
The summarize() function creates a new data frame. This data frame will have rows for each combination of grouping variables. These grouping variables are specified by group_by(). The columns in this data frame are the summary statistics you have specified (ex. mean(), max(), min(), sd(), etc.)
Here is an example of using the summarize() function:
In this example I’m grouping by species, and island, and then finding the mean and standard deviation for flipper length (in mm) for those groups.


mean_sd_penguins <- penguins %>% 
  group_by(species, island) %>% 
  summarize(mean_flipper_length = mean(flipper_length_mm, na.rm = TRUE),
            sd_flipper_length = sd(flipper_length_mm, na.rm = TRUE))

mean_sd_penguins


# A tibble: 5 × 4
# Groups:   species [3]
  species   island    mean_flipper_length sd_flipper_length
  <fct>     <fct>                   <dbl>             <dbl>
1 Adelie    Biscoe                   189.              6.73
2 Adelie    Dream                    190.              6.59
3 Adelie    Torgersen                191.              6.23
4 Chinstrap Dream                    196.              7.13
5 Gentoo    Biscoe                   217.              6.48

title: Using ggplot
description: An example using ggplot to plot data.
contents:
ggplot() is a function that makes different kinds of plots. This example uses data from the palmerpenguins dataset and shows body mass vs flipper length. The graph shown below is a scatterplot, defined by geom_point(). The graph also is colored by species, using geom_point(aes(color = species)).


ggplot(data = penguins, aes(x = flipper_length_mm, y = body_mass_g)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = species)) +
  labs(title = "Body Mass vs Flipper Length", 
       x = " Flipper Length (mm)", 
       y = "Body Mass (g)")
